title: Spud Lathe - peel fruit or vegetables with a cordless drill

description.text:
Inspired by a facebook video that my wife showed me: https://www.facebook.com/video.php?v=539637342822833
I tried it with potatoes, but now that I looked it up again, I find that chef van Ramshorst was peeling apples in the video. I guess that makes more sense since they would be more symmetrical to begin with -- I wasted a lot of potato before getting all the peel off! Still, you have to attach the fruit or vegetable to the drill somehow... . It would be more effective with the type of peeler in the video as well, but I used what I had on hand.

Rotate the .stl so that it lays flat before printing.  If you're planning on doing apples you may want to scale it down: This is sized for maximum strength and fits a 3/8-inch drill.  The .scad file has a provision for a third prong, but my test showed it to be unnecessary.  
For regular use I would think printing in ABS and vapor-treating it would make it more sanitary: You could likely run it through the dishwasher on the upper rack.

credit goes to the unknown maker

the value for the fan width (labeled as diameter) means the outer edge length of the fan's frame
it's not the diameter of the fan blade hole nor the screws distant

this time mounted the fan onto the holder with zip ties (needed it fast)
next time a you could change the design to omit the badges for the nuts or make them going over the hole bar width

comments.text: Last year I taught one of our CAD classes, but our Principles of Engineering classes also use the 3D printer. Students are taught Autodesk inventor and depending on the teacher and the activity, when ever there is a new part to be designed and fabricated it starts as an Inventor drawing and then gets tweaked to be a printable part on our dimension BST 1200 printer. If the part works as expected it can then be machining on our Tormach PCNC 1100 CNC mill. Or just used as is out of the printer. We have made parts for engineering projects,  the schools FIRST robotics team (team 871), automotive class projects, etc. there is a monte carlo with an ABS seat motor adapter :-)

author: boatmegeve

description.text: This is not a thing you're likely to specifically need.  This is here just to spark some ideas.  My wife bought an acrylic lion figure at a flea market, and it came with a pretty ugly lighted wooden base.  When the light burned out and I went to get a replacement, I found these nice blue LED candelabra base, night-lite type bulbs.  They were much too cool for the old base, so I printed this base.  It's not perfect, but it made the wife happy, and scored a few points.

Although I uploaded the .scad and .stl files, you're not likely to need this specific base, so more important is just a few of the ideas used here. The lamp socket is cheap and readily available here: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000UID44G/ref=ox_sc_act_title_1?ie=UTF8&psc=1&smid=A1ZEMTT4HTM149 I found the LED candelabra night-lite bulb at Wal-Mart, but haven't been able to find it online. Cheap at 2/$4. The one I used is blue, which worked out perfect. The packaging sort of implies that there are other colors available, but I didn't see any. The brand is Meridian #13116B. The light from the bulb is directional vertically, so the base had to be tall enough to hold the socket and bulb in that orientation. The socket has metal spring 'wings' on the sides that compress and hold it in place when you shove it in a one inch hole. The channel in the bottom for the AC wire to exit features some 'bumps' which help to hold the wire in place. Slide the cord in by the narrow edge, then twist it flat and it will stay in place. I printed this in Octave glow-in-the-dark blue ABS, which was perfect with the blue bulb, but other than when the LED is on, I haven't noticed any glowing in the dark. The other interesting thing with this item was that it's the first thing I've tried finishing with acetone vapor. This was mentioned in the Makerbot group, which pointed to a blog post on the Solidoodle forum at: http://solidoodletips.wordpress.com/2012/11/10/presto-part-finisher/
The basic idea is to get a Presto model 06006 deep fryer, put a few tablespoons of acetone in it, place your part in the steaming basket into the fryer, cover and turn on at the lowest setting. The acetone readily vaporizes and deposits evenly on all of the surfaces and leaves a remarkable finish. You don't have to have a whole pot of acetone to dip an item. Needless to say, read all of the instructions and observe the safety precautions mentioned in that post. See the attached pic, and no, don't do this in the house.

This adapts a 1.25" inner diameter (~1.32" outer diameter) PVC pipe to the accessory attachment on a small "shark" style handheld vacuum, in this case, the TURBOVAC 600. It is similar to the Euro-Pro EP033 Shark handheld. I wanted an extension "wand" so I could get at crevasses, etc. on the floor or up high while standing normally. That shark model seems to have a similar attachment, but it is up to you to make the measurements; your mileage may vary. It works so far, but the PVC adapter section is a tad loose; I printed it in PLA and used slurry to attach it, but it's slipped off. Once I fix it, I will re-post the proper files.

CAUTION: WORK IN PROGRESS.
Make it solid. Should glue onto the PVC with a bit of slurry (I have considered tapering the round end). The round bit of the print should fit around one end of the PVC pipe (round). The opposite end of the pipe can be shaped to fit on an attachment (like the brush shown) by heating it with a hairdryer until it is pliable and working it onto the attachment. Once cool, it will hold its shape.

I like the design by Mattasmack and have tweaked it a little bit.
I like things hidden so moved the bracket in the centre so added a transition piece (orange) to achieve this. The bracket (green)and the shade (red) now become symmetrical and you get another degree of freedom as well. The swing arm can also be made smaller, use the "swing arm short" file. A screw attaches the transition piece to the bracket. A bolt and wing nut can be used to tie the transition block and swing arm together. The "wall sconce centered" file is for illustration of the assembly only. Also look at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:488720 it is an improvement IMHO.

comments.text: That's a cool variation on the design!  I like how, with the bracket centered, it can swing equally well left or right.  I'm curious to know how the extra joint you added works out.  I've avoided joints like that - where gravity is opposed by friction - out of concern that it will slip down over time.  But I've never tried it, so I don't know!

This is a derivative of Madox's Mini Centrifugal Pump, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4839 I simplified the design and adapted it to be printable on a makerbot without support material. I also modified it so that the motor from an old CD-Rom drive can run the pump. These motors are all about the same size, and anyone who likes to take things apart more then likely has a few laying around. In the photos I am powering a 6 volt motor with a 3.5 volt battery. I imagine more power would equal more water moved.

1) Print out all three parts, the Base, Impeller and Casing.  
2) Drill out the center of the impeller so it fits on the motor's shaft
3) Use a knife to cut the support tower out of the center of the casing
4) Press the motor firmly into the top of the casing
5) Press the impeller down onto the motor shaft, but not all the way. Leave a little space between the top of the impeller and the base of the housing.
6) Power the motor and use sandpaper against the spinning impeller to smooth out any high spots
7) Press the base on
DONE!
The real magic of this, is that if you have the motor, it takes less than a half hour to download, print, and assemble.

comments.text: My CD/DVD motor, (I have 2 and both are the same), has the shaft connected to the outer body. In other words, the outer body and shaft spin as one piece. How would you get this to work with this design and still be water proof, since the outer assembly spins also? The shaft does not come out of the motor, it is part of the assembly.

This is a stand that will cradle your nexus 7 either in landscape or portrait orientation.  However the charger can only be used when it is in Landscape mode.  
The micro USB chord simply is pressed through small gates underneath the stand and can run to either side of your device.
I haven't printed this one yet, but I made the tolerances pretty large so even if your printer is not the most accurate, it should still hold the nexus pretty well (I used roughly+- .007"; that would be a total tolerance of .014")

Before you hit the print button, make sure you're in inches..
Enjoy!

author: sduvally

description.text:
These clips are meant to be used along with plexi/lexan panels to enclose your Rigidbot (regular size) for the purposes of preventing drafts from warping delicate parts, and fume extraction.
It's meant to be as small as possible while still allowing the printer its full range of motion. The front and rear panels stick out to allow the table to move past the frame, the top panels allow room for the gantry when it gets to the top of its travel. The spool rack must be moved from the side of the frame to the back, with an extended rod.

Use at your own risk - I am not responsible for any injury or damage, etc.
Parts needed:
-lexan panels, 18x24" is ideal to minimize cutting
-M3 x 10mm screws, qty 4
-CA glue (superglue)
-8mm x 47cm spool rod
-means of cutting lexan (prefer dremel and jigsaw)
-drill and 3mm bit
Read through all these steps before starting! This is just a general guide. I know these will be long prints, so set them for low quality. On mine I ended up printing everything shorter and taping the seams.
  • Panels are to be cut as shown on the drawing. I suggest cutting them as you go and confirming fitment along the way. Cut two of each panel size except the "top horizontal" panel, which only needs to be cut once.
  • Use the "lexan side upper supports" and "lexan side lower supports" to attach the left and right lexan panels. Do not glue the panels to the lower supports, doing so would make it difficult to remove the enclosure. Line up the upper supports, mark and drill the panel, then screw the panel to the upper supports.
  • Glue the "front and rear panel sliders - bottom" to the four bottom corners of the left and right lexan panels. The larger slots should face inward and that's what the front and rear panels will slide into.
  • Glue the "front and rear panel sliders - top" above the bottom sliders from step 3
  • Glue the "front and rear top cover mounts" to the upper edges of the left and right panels, on the front and back, then glue the "front and rear (top)" panels in place.
  • Set the "diagonal panel lower mounts" on the top of the frame on the front and rear side. Glue them to the "front and rear (top)" lexan panel.
  • Glue the "top diagonal" panels into the mounts from step 6.
  • Glue the "top center cover angled clips" to the "top horizontal" panel, leaving a gap in the middle for the filament to be passed through. Then glue this part onto the top sides of the "top diagonal" panels.
  • Trace and cut the trapezoid shape for the side panels needed to close in the top part. I was never able to draw this and have it work out, so I am saying to trace it instead. Leave a bit of a gap for the clips.
  • Glue the "top center cover 90deg clips) to the top edges of the trapezoid panels, and the "top diagonal cover 90deg clips" to the diagonal parts. Then glue this to the sides of the top diagonal and top horizontal panels.
  • Figure out which panel you want the fume extraction fan to be placed, trace it and cut it out. Screw the fan to the plexi from the inside, then find and print an adapter to connect whatever size duct you are using, to the fan.
  • Move the posts for the spool rack from the side to the back of the frame, and reinstall with the longer rod.
    If you need to remove the enclosure, simply undo the 4 screws on the side panels and the whole shebang should lift off.

title: Nema 17 Holders for Wirechain Prusa i3

description.text:
2015-02-26
I seperated the part for the Z-axis. The old design reduced the max height of printing parts. Install the axis holder on the plate and attach the chain guide with 2 M3 screws.
  • Work in progress *
    The concept is, that all wires from the Extruder and the x-axis stepper go to the upper left corner via wirechains and from there to the RAMPS board on the back of the printer.
    Use the chain parts from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10946 (Wire-chain-20mm-Link-sNi (1).stl).
    One part goes on the extruders stepper, the other one on the x axis stepper. Put your cables inside and enjoy the your well wired Prusa i3.
    • Use this nice design for the Y Axis
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:57533

comments.text: I made one of these to tidy up my wiring - see the photos in 'Made'. All worked very well, but one extra feature would make it perfect - the 'z-axis-top' part needs a cable tray underneath to collect the wires from the chains and guide them neatly to the back of the aluminium frame.  Either that, or a small plate vertically from front to back with a line of holes for cable ties.

This is a snap-on holster that makes it easy to keep an extension nozzle paired with the can of product that it's used with.  Great for compressed air, silicone spray, lubricant sprays, etc.  So now you can ditch the cellophane tape that's always hard to manage.  This is the new improved version 2 that has a leaf spring hoding method.  The original one that relied on pinching the tube in a short distance made for a sensitive design.  This new one works great.

The inside diameter is 2-1/2" and snaps onto at 2-5/8" can with relative ease. You can scale it up or down to fit properly other sized cans.  But keep in mind that too much a change will effect the fit of the nozzle.  The sizing works will for ABS, not sure about the differences with PLA being used, probably just a tighter fit.  Make with three perimeters and save the work of filling in the center with excessive movements.

I wanted to hang a paper towel holder on my pegboard. Many of the hangers require that you screw the hanger into the pegboard. I wanted the flexibility of being able to move the hangers where and when I want to so I designed a towel holder that accomplishes that. It is designed for pegboards with 1 inch spacing like those sold by Home Depot and other home improvement centers.

Settings (Suggested)
Raft: On
Supports: On
Infill: 35% Suggested to make sure 'pegs' are strong.
Shells: 3
Layer Height: 0.20mm Print with the arrow on back pointing down towards build plate. Or, with rod opening facing up. After printing,clean up and remove raft and supports with an xacto knife. Be careful not to damage pegs during cleaning. File as necessary for good fit in pegboard. I used a 3/4 inch OD piece of conduit but a 3/4 inch wooden dowel rod would be good as well.

These are full-scale, magnetic resonance image-generated models of two ascending aorta aneurysms (i.e. the ascending portion of the aorta is enlarged compared to normal individuals). Both occurred due to a congenitally occurring bicuspid aortic valve. In one, fittings have been mocked up to understand the feasibility of creating in-vitro flow phantoms for imaging via MRI. I've printed both with good results.
Both print out nicely on the Replicator 2X at standard resolution. No rafts or supports. At full scale, they took something like 2.5-3 hours. I used 10-15% infill.

This is a 3D scan of a pumpkin with a face. It is a demo model from the LMI HDI Advance scanner. I added 2 models: one is the original scan that is difficult to 3D print because of holes and high amount of data (FacePumpkinRaw.stl). The other has been reduced, oriented and made solid for easier 3D printing (FacePumpkinSolid.stl). This was done with MeshMixer, download it for free at http://www.meshmixer.com.
In MeshMixer there is the ''Make Solid'' option, basically a model will get digitally ''shrinkwrapped'' to create a new solid model. http://www.3dwp.nl

The stock Flashforge 30mm spool hangers are fine for spools with larger diameters. However, the stock retaining nut is so small (see picture) that spools with larger hub openings can fall off of the hangers when moving the bot around. The big hubs (see other picture) have the same 30mm thread and are wide enough to restrain even the largest spools.
22 Oct 14: Added a smaller version of the big hub nut. Should require considerably less filament but it's still large enough to restrain spools with larger diameter openings. March 2015: There are reports of a larger 50mm spool holder tube appearing on newer Flashforge printers. Obviously these won't fit the larger tubes, so measure first.

There are two STL files included. The smaller "nut" file is cut from the big hub and so shares the same thread profile. Use the "nut" to tweak your settings to get a good fit that will thread onto the end of the spool hanger, without having to invest all of the time and material to test-print the main piece.

title: i3 rework hall based auto bed levelling probe

description.text:
Automaticly retracts, based on the design from MarcoAntonini and adapted for prusa i3 rework extruder and mount.
No extra width for the X-carriage, and no servo needed.
I found it to be more consistent then the servo mounted mechanical switch that I previously used. Parts needed:
  • This printed part
  • A hall-0 probe (the arrow shaped one, I got mine from mauk.cc
  • A probe (I used a long nail with the head grinded off)
  • 2x 5x5x5 magnet

Update: 13-02-12: Updated the scad file, with guards, and stl with larger radii under where the bearing should sit. I was having an issue with clearance while printing so I added 1mm of space.
Update 13-02-10: Updated the scad file with some spool guards on the outside of the frame. Should help the spool from falling off. I may need to add them on the inside as well but I am hoping that since the roller is one piece the outsides will be enough. Derived from thing:22579 as there were a couple issues with scaling the spool. I tried to make sure the base radii were flush (or as flush as possible in the case of the long side cut outs) with all spool sizes to minimize material and eliminate overhangs. Also tried to give a suitable variable value to the length of it to keep the spool stable.

I've printed versions with as little as 15% infil (all have been PLA) and they work fine. The file should be parametric but I haven't tested it for a boat load of different spool sizes or bearings.
Currently I have 608 bearings so I re-designed it for them but it should work with other types. I use mine with some extra threaded rod I have left over, or you can use 8mm bolts, smooth rod, bundles of filament, etc.
I'm still looking to add in a design to help guard the spool from coming off the sides as it gets lighter.
The included .stl is for my spool at 204mm in diameter and 72.5mm wide (including the walls).

author: Ferretti

title: Linear bearing made of three bearings

description.text:
UPDATE:

  • Cleaned up some support lines

    • Added a weight saving option to cut out some unneeded bits.
    Fixed some errors where supports didn't reach all the way.
    Added comments to the code.
    Description
    --
    I was looking for a new linear bearing to use for the x carriage on a printer. This is my first attempt, and f me it works. It's not very parameterised, I'll look at changing that later.
    Currently it works with 623 bearings (10mm wide, 4mm wide, 3mm hole in the middle).
    The nice thing about this design is that it deals with lateral force much better than little linear bearings. The one in the picture is smooth to move where ever you apply the force.
    The three bearings are held against the rod at equal intervals. The design is in four parts, with four units joined together forming a full carriage. The picture is of half the carriage running on one rail.
    It's designed for my printer which is an i3 prusa, so the full carriage sits on two 8mm rails sat 45mm apart.

Print both parts, I used Cura with grid support on everything. Hack out the support material, there's a lot in the quarter that holds two bearings.
The bearings are held in with 12mm hex cap screws for the side with two, and ... others. I should measure them.
The two halves don't quite meet in the middle, this is by design. The half with the flat surface has slightly larger holes, this is to allow you to feed the screws through, they then screw into the other half which has smaller holes.
it uses 3 * 623zz bearings internally, ideally pad the sides with m3 washers, but it doesn't have to be a tight.

title: Asus EeeTop Wall Hanger with Power Brick Clamps

description.text:
This is just a simple hook designed to mount a EeeTop model: ET2203 as well as the ET2203T to the wall without any modifications or damage.
Though if you use the Power Supply clamps, you'll have to drill 4 small holes to mount it.

I printed the hook at %100 fill, but that was overkill.  I would print it at ~30% in the future.
You'll also need a 2x4 that is at least 10" to mount the hook on.  First, mount the 2x4 to the wall by whatever means nessicary (I screwed it into a stud), then mount the hanger to the board at the appropriate height to the board will sit just below the stands curve; using 1.2-2" screws.   The pictures will help this make sense.
The power supply I used was non-OEM, to help with some power issues I was having.  It was mounted by drilling 4 small holes in the PC housing.
I love having a big touch computer in the kitchen, its fantastic for long cooking sessions and reference.

title: Gearbox Cover for an HSP Bayer RC Car.

description.text:
My friend has an HSP Bayer RC car.
The original Gearbox cover melted. We thought it would be worth trying to print one, but we knew that if the original melted, it would be a challenge for printed plastic. Especially when you add the heat of the desert here in Dubai.
After a few iterations this is the final version. It worked but after 7 minutes the plastic was starting to get soft. What we realized is, now that we have this STL file, an approach to an engineering firm to get one milled out of aluminum using a CNC machine is the answer.
Feel free to try printing this out of plastic if you want to, but I am sure the engine heat will cause you problems. But if you want one milled from metal, this is all you need.
If you do make one of these (from plastic or metal), let me know how you get on.

This is my updated version of the RepRap Mendel Y Pulley.  Designed to bring the belt teeth out beyond the stepper mount and still have plenty of pulley on the shaft to insure the rotation is true.  Unique is the second part that is glued (use a little Super Glue) to cap the end of the pulley and capture the belt.

Print, Cleanup, us a dot of super glue to glue the cap on the end.  Enjoy.  Let me know if you have any issues.  The hole for the small outline M3 nut can be a bit tight.  I used a tap hammer and screw driver to set mine in the slot.
I included the Inventor Fusion file so you can edit it if you would like to.
The teeth are a bit different then the stock part and should insure no extraneous play which would lead to accuracy errors.

title: 3D printed pins to secure one end of the super-cool Hyperbolic Planetary Gear design

description.text:
Because I didn't have a half dozen #10 hex screws available, and a "purer' (not purest) approach would be to have all printed parts, I made these pins that mostly fit flush with the curve ends, and look a lot nicer.
Printed in with 3 layers seems to have sufficient strength. The angles help the pins to hold the top pice together pretty well. The .STL includes a small support, since my version of Maker ware would print supports for such a small area, and 2 of 3 attempted printes failed without the 2mm support column that's easily snapped off

Just another filament spool, designed to be makerbot printable, relatively cheap to make and free spinning, and it doesn't require an overly tuned makerbot to print. Inspired in part by : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4641 which is an even easier option for a filament spool Also usefull as a cheap revolving tabletop thing (note that the spokes tilt slightly upwards before attempting to put anything flat on it), unsure yet of how much weight it will hold. I'm planning on adding more components (such as a bolt on filament guide and central core to hold the filament neatly) so more to come. Note: Numbers on part filenames are just part of my rudimentry version management 01-DEC-2010: Filament Guide Add-on Kit now available from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4982

Effort Required
Minimal Effort, Total Estimated Print time for printed parts is about 10 hoours or so. Parts Note
Refer Parts List attached Atleast 3x but preferably about 10x Marbles (around 16mm Diameter or anywhere near that is fine) Until I add more parts to create the middle section for the filament you'll need something heavy and round to stick in the middle (a 50cd/dvd spindle works quite nicely) Assembly

  • Bolt 5 of the SupportSection7 componenets together into a ring as per the photo, there are two 4mm diameter holes on each side of the components.

  • Seperate out the SpokePrintAssembly component into 5 individuaul spokes and bolt them on to the outer edge of the ring from step 1

  • Bolt 5 of the BaseSection9 components together into a ring as per the photo, there are two 4mm diameter holes on each side of the components

  • (This step is optional but highly recommended) Sand down the marble tracks so they are very smooth and free of sharp edges or bumps etc. I like to use sandpaper, then steel-wool and then a brass polishing liquid (this works similar to acetone but leaves a matt finish, it will discolor the plastic though) to get a nice smooth finish.

  • Roughly distribute atleast 3 but preferably more (10 or so is good) marbles onto the base ring you made in step 3 (don't worry to much they'll shift around and distribute on their own over time), if you only use a few marbles you will probably find they eventually all huddle together for warmth, so just add more marbles until this isn't a problem.

  • Pop the top ring over the marbles

  • Add some weight (it spins much better when its weighed down a little), put your filament on and you're ready to go

  • If you're printing a plain turntable stop here

  • If you want to add a Filament Guide head on over to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4982 for the Filament Guide Addon Kit

title: Anti-Jam Guide for Printrbot Alum Extruder

description.text:
I made this to stop the filament from pushing out of the hobbed gear for Printrbot's Aluminum Extruder that is on my Simple Metal. This has completely fixed my issue of not extruding filament early in the print, some say heat causes the filament to bend out, I think it is from the filament being coiled up.
Be sure to pick the appropriate stl for mounting to the right or left sides.

I printed this at .2mm with 100% fill.
Simply undo the screw that holds the feed bearing on the extruder, and screw it back into place, sandwiching the Anti-Jam Guide between it and the extruder.
Be sure to mirror this if the bearing screw is on the left side.

This design is for my fiancÃÂ© who likes to run while holding her iPod in her hand (leading to the inevitable falling and shattering that you may be able to see on the screen). I'm hoping this wristband will help avoid that. This one is printed all at once and snaps together. There is no single clasp: each joint is equally detachable, but they snap apart perpendicular to the band, so it's still secure on your wrist. 
What I've noticed about snap-fit joints is that they always come out a little differently on different printers. Therefore this one is customizable to different tolerances, as well as different band width, thickness, etc. This one is also oriented differently than most, giving a more secure mount.

Print it as is, or open the Customizer app to tweak it as you see fit. The length parameter is the circumference of your wrist, though you can always make it too long. You can just snap off a few segments to make it shorter. By inputting your build platform's x-dimension, it will automatically break the band into pieces such that it all fits. 
This might be a good OpenSCAD script to look at if you want to learn about designing for Customizer, as it's much simpler than most of my designs, but includes some fun features.

description.text: un cenicero en forma de colmillos

I thought Ansarum's awesome Minecraft jack o'lantern was really cool, but it needed some bug fixes and an easy way to illuminate it. So, I' have scaled it up and adjusted the lid so that it fits. The version with a hole in the bottom is designed to fit these flickering led tea lights from Amazon. Enjoy!

Print with support!   
There are two versions.  The first is flat bottomed and works like a real jack o'lantern -- just drop in a LED tea light through the top.   
The design with the hole through is more ambitious.  The LED light is meant to friction fit in the hole, but it doesn't really work very well.  
Perhaps in an update I'll be able to reliably hold inserted tea lights in place, but as it stands the tea light will either fall out unless wrapped in tape or else the hole will print too small and you'll need to trim it down.

Only had to shve the notch a hair to get a nice sliding fit.

description.text:
Flying Spaghetti Monster inspired iPhone 6 case.
Updated final alternate stl with full tail and bridged buttons. With the fish being a large bridge, slicer didn't like auto support when 'don't support bridges' was unchecked but printed great without support...Ramen.

title: Twist lock extrusion clip for 2020 extrusions

description.text: Just the beginning of a quick idea for a T Clip substitute when you don't want to take things apart or buy the roll in type of tclips. Still needs a little tweaking, but overall a good working idea for a quick mount of fans,etc.

I printed this with a .35 nozzle and .25 layers. I didn't use support, but had to clean up the underside of the clip afterwards. Maybe support would be easier. I made the main hole a little small if you wanted to just use a screw in it, or you can use an M3 screw and a nut on the backside. Again, I made the nut area tight so it would hold the nut well, but still needs some fine tuning.
To install, just lock a nut underneath (or nothing if using a screw), place the tab into the extrusion, and turn 90 degrees while pressing in on the center a bit. It will lock in place when fully installed.

title: Rostock Max V2 TPE / Ninjaflex Custom Extruder for soft filaments

description.text:
I had a real struggle trying to print ninjaflex on the rostock max v2 and even with the filament support mods people suggest I didn't have any luck.
I designed this extruder and so far it hasn't had any issues with printing soft or normal filaments.
I used the factory red lever from the Ezstruder assembly along with its spring and other hardware that I had left over from the rostock kit. If you don't have any of that hardware around you can easily source it at a local hardware store.

You will have to drill out the bottom of the extruder to the right size hole to self tape the tubing coupler into the extruder. I found it was best to tap this by hand instead of trying to print a hole the right size. It works but after a while it may weaken.. so far by drilling and taping the hole by hand this has worked out with no problems.
The rest you can see from the photos.. I used two zip ties to hold the nema 17 motor in place since the rostock mounts were now gone. This has proved to be more than sturdy so designing motor mounts never happened.

comments.text: Hey guys, thanks for all the comments. I made this in 3ds MAX, so i don't have any source files, no idea where the original max files are at this point. I made this, printed it out without any issues. I did have to make slight adjustments to it with a file or knife I can't remember. However its been working great for me ever since, even in PLA form.

title: Supercase for Raspberry Pi B+ with 3.5 Inch TFT Screen

description.text:
This is a Raspberry Pi B+ Case. It also hold a 3.5 Inch TFT Screen. It is made of nine 3.25mm pieces that all connect with four - 3mm screws. Its very easy to print and assemble. Print each piece in any color you want and then just assemble in order 1 through 9.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1o5p7uk3m2E&list=UUyaDLFFWIrpx2VX8a2fBEeQ

Slicing instructions:  Make sure you print with a fill rate of 30% and a layer thickness of .25mm.  This way all pieces will be 3.25mm and they will each have 13 layers.  Slice everything with support.  Only a few pieces need it, but better to be safe.

description.text: It's a flying disc toy inspired by bat man.
Print it out. Throw it. YAY! I made some in PLA as well as ABS. The PLA ones break if if they hit a wall too hard. The ABS ones are nigh-invulnerable.

A different way to hold the heat sink. It slides into the profile and fits snugly. A drop of superglue will hold it there quite well. There are two different kind of swing arms. One extends a little further out and hence has more movement of the attached light. The other has the hinge towards the inside of the swing arm so mounts closer to the wall but has not as much adjustment possible. Still to be updated is the shade, That has now been done. It is a tight fit but that is how you want it so it will stay in place with friction only. If you slice it at 101% it fits just right. After looking at it for a while I decided that it was not that important to be able to swing the lamp so redesigned the wall plate that allows only up and down movement. If you use 22 gauge wire the leads can be neatly tucked away underneath. Combined with copper foil stuck on the wall and painted over nobody will ever see the power supply to the light. I made three of them as shown in the pictures. They all turned out great.
The last four pictures are of one of the lights installed on the wall. I used copper foil for the conductor as you can see. The second picture shows the light lit. And the copper foil attached to the wall. The third picture shows the power supply soldered onto the copper foil. The last picture shows the lit light and the foil painted over. Now it's hidden!
That's just the way I like my cords...invisible.
Enjoy.
Printed in standard .3mm layer, 2 perimeters and 30% infill in PLA should work equally well in ABS

This is a derivative of my first cup holder adapter, this one is slightly wider in the bottom and has a tapered opening.
This is to better accommodate tall fast food drink cups.

title: Modular Eppendorf Tube Rack
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Have you ever wanted to store an infinite amount of PCR tubes? Have you ever dreamed of having a 1.6 mL tube rack that is spaced for multi-channel access? Well now it is all possible!  
Let me rephrase: This is a test tube rack designed for molecular biologists. Each module holds 16x PCR tubes or 4x 1.6 mL tubes or 4x 600 uL tubes. The modules clip together so you can assemble whatever type of rack you want. I am planning to make some adapters as well that clip into the system that allow you to use lids, etc.   
PCR tubes fit quite snugly into the rack if you push them all the way down, which is nice for freezer storage since they won't fall all over the floor if you happen to drop the rack on the ground. They can also fit into freezer boxes, allowing you to store more PCR tubes per freezer box than before.

title: Customizable plant pot with elevated drainage holes

description.text:
A round pot with holes at the bottom.
You can customize height, radius, hole size and more.

This pot is designed to be placed inside a cachepot or a plant saucer.
It can be produced with a standard FDM printer (in my case a German Reprap Neo) without any need for support structures.
You can freely define the height of the pot, as well as its upper and lower diameter.

This solid ring at the top improves the stability of the pot.
Its walls are cylindrical with thickness and height of your choice.
The holes belong to the the lowest points of inside. They are located near the outside of the pot and have a customizable size.

The slats at the bottom elevate the holes by a certain amount, so all excess water can escape, even if there is already some water in the cachepot.
Since I wanted the slats to be a part of the pot, the "roofs" above the slats were necessary to make sure that there is no overhang of more than 45° to make it more reliable for production.
Actually I didn't do any reasearch what overhangs will work with which materials and printers, but 45° seemed to be a safe bet.

description.text:
文字化け放置を修正(^▽^;)
(何を書いてたのか覚えてないので...) ヘッド部分は簡易的な追加ガイドでPTFEチューブを使用したものです。 モータ部分のベルトテンショナーは、筐体がMDFで使用しているとベルトのテンションによって筐体が歪みテンションが狂いやすいBS01用のものとなります。
その為、筐体がアクリルのidboxの場合は、使用する必要は無いです。
(MDF筐体よりテンショナーアームがスムーズに動く為に、状況に依っては取り付けると逆効果になりますので注意してください)

author: ichibey

title: Printrbot simple 1405 part 1116 no sag mod

description.text:
My take on trying to reduce the sag on the printrbot simple y axis. Just added flanges to part 1116 of the printrbot simple 1405 to hold the lm8uu bearings in place better and reduce wobbling. The part is divided in 2 so that it's easier to print (one of the stl parts is upside down, flange down, remember to flip before you print). The 2 halves are held together well enough by all the screws and zip ties.
It's probably not as good as the "Printrbot Simple, 300mm Y Axis-No Sag!" by iamjonlawrence, but its good if your not up to modifying your printrbot simple too much.
-mupp-

comments.text: Have you noticed any difference with this mod ?
comments.author: sambert20

comments.text: It does considerably decrease the sagging. I usually get 1 - 2 mm of sagging when the Y axis is at max, the mod reduces it to less than half that for me. But you have to be careful of the warping though, since it may cause the y axis to be slightly misaligned. But since nobody else has given me any feedback I cant really say how it works for everyone, heheh..
